synsets.definition: consider or hold as true
_examples: I cannot accept the dogma of this church
accept an argument

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: give an affirmative reply to; respond favorably to
_examples: I cannot accept your invitation
I go for this resolution

synsets.definition: react favorably to; consider right and proper
_examples: People did not accept atonal music at that time
We accept the idea of universal health care

synsets.definition: admit into a group or community
_examples: accept students for graduate study
We'll have to vote on whether or not to admit a new member

synsets.definition: take on as one's own the expenses or debts of another person
_examples: I'll accept the charges
She agreed to bear the responsibility

synsets.definition: tolerate or accommodate oneself to
_examples: I shall have to accept these unpleasant working conditions
I swallowed the insult
She has learned to live with her husband's little idiosyncrasies

synsets.definition: be designed to hold or take
_examples: This surface will not take the dye

synsets.definition: receive (a report) officially, as from a committee
make use of or accept for some purpose
_examples: take a risk
take an opportunity

synsets.definition: be sexually responsive to, used of a female domesticated mammal
_examples: The cow accepted the bull

synsets.definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
_examples: She has $1,000 in the bank
He has got two beautiful daughters
She holds a Master's degree from Harvard

synsets.definition: have as a feature
_examples: This restaurant features the most famous chefs in France

synsets.definition: go through (mental or physical states or experiences)
_examples: get an idea
experience vertigo
get nauseous
receive injuries
have a feeling

synsets.definition: have ownership or possession of
_examples: He owns three houses in Florida
How many cars does she have?

synsets.definition: cause to move; cause to be in a certain position or condition
_examples: He got his squad on the ball
This let me in for a big surprise
He got a girl into trouble

synsets.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
_examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

synsets.definition: have a personal or business relationship with someone
_examples: have a postdoc
have an assistant
have a lover

synsets.definition: organize or be responsible for
_examples: hold a reception
have, throw, or make a party
give a course

synsets.definition: have left
_examples: I have two years left

They have two more years before they retire

synsets.definition: be confronted with
_examples: What do we have here?
Now we have a fine mess

synsets.definition: undergo
_examples: The stocks had a fast run-up

synsets.definition: suffer from; be ill with
_examples: She has arthritis

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: get something; come into possession of
_examples: receive payment
receive a gift
receive letters from the front

synsets.definition: undergo (as of injuries and illnesses)
_examples: She suffered a fracture in the accident

synsets.definition: achieve a point or goal
_examples: Nicklaus had a 70

She made 29 points that day

synsets.definition: cause to be born
_examples: My wife had twins yesterday!

synsets.definition: have sex with; archaic use
_examples: He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

knowledges.origin_sent: Now I have a thousand dollars, and a football phone!

synsets.definition: assign a specified (usually proper) proper name to
_examples: They named their son David
The new school was named after the famous Civil Rights leader

synsets.definition: ascribe a quality to or give a name of a common noun that reflects a quality
_examples: He called me a bastard
She called her children lazy and ungrateful

synsets.definition: get or try to get into communication (with someone) by telephone
_examples: I tried to call you all night
Take two aspirin and call me in the morning

synsets.definition: utter a sudden loud cry
_examples: she cried with pain when the doctor inserted the needle
I yelled to her from the window but she couldn't hear me

synsets.definition: order, request, or command to come
_examples: She was called into the director's office
Call the police!

synsets.definition: pay a brief visit
_examples: The mayor likes to call on some of the prominent citizens

synsets.definition: call a meeting; invite or command to meet
_examples: The Wannsee Conference was called to discuss the `Final Solution'
The new dean calls meetings every week

synsets.definition: read aloud to check for omissions or absentees
_examples: Call roll

synsets.definition: send a message or attempt to reach someone by radio, phone, etc.; make a signal to in order to transmit a message
_examples: Hawaii is calling!
A transmitter in Samoa was heard calling

synsets.definition: utter a characteristic note or cry
_examples: bluejays called to one another

synsets.definition: stop or postpone because of adverse conditions, such as bad weather
_examples: call a football game

synsets.definition: greet, as with a prescribed form, title, or name
_examples: He always addresses me with `Sir'
Call me Mister
She calls him by first name

synsets.definition: make a stop in a harbour
_examples: The ship will call in Honolulu tomorrow

synsets.definition: demand payment of (a loan)
_examples: Call a loan

synsets.definition: make a demand, as for a card or a suit or a show of hands
_examples: He called his trump

synsets.definition: give the calls (to the dancers) for a square dance
indicate a decision in regard to

synsets.definition: make a prediction about; tell in advance
_examples: Call the outcome of an election

synsets.definition: require the presentation of for redemption before maturation
_examples: Call a bond

synsets.definition: challenge (somebody) to make good on a statement; charge with or censure for an offense
_examples: He deserves to be called on that

synsets.definition: declare in the capacity of an umpire or referee
_examples: call a runner out

synsets.definition: lure by imitating the characteristic call of an animal
_examples: Call ducks

synsets.definition: order or request or give a command for
_examples: The unions called a general strike for Sunday

synsets.definition: order, summon, or request for a specific duty or activity, work, role
_examples: He was already called 4 times for jury duty
They called him to active military duty

synsets.definition: utter in a loud voice or announce
_examples: He called my name

synsets.definition: challenge the sincerity or truthfulness of
_examples: call the speaker on a question of fact

synsets.definition: consider or regard as being
_examples: I would not call her beautiful

synsets.definition: rouse somebody from sleep with a call
_examples: I was called at 5 A.M. this morning

synsets.definition: undergo an emotional sensation or be in a particular state of mind
_examples: She felt resentful
He felt regret

synsets.definition: come to believe on the basis of emotion, intuitions, or indefinite grounds
_examples: I feel that he doesn't like me
I find him to be obnoxious
I found the movie rather entertaining

synsets.definition: perceive by a physical sensation, e.g., coming from the skin or muscles
_examples: He felt the wind
She felt an object brushing her arm
He felt his flesh crawl
She felt the heat when she got out of the car

synsets.definition: be conscious of a physical, mental, or emotional state
_examples: My cold is gone--I feel fine today
She felt tired after the long hike
She felt sad after her loss

synsets.definition: have a feeling or perception about oneself in reaction to someone's behavior or attitude
_examples: She felt small and insignificant
You make me feel naked
I made the students feel different about themselves

synsets.definition: undergo passive experience of:"We felt the effects of inflation"
_examples: her fingers felt their way through the string quartet
she felt his contempt of her

synsets.definition: be felt or perceived in a certain way
_examples: The ground feels shaky
The sheets feel soft

synsets.definition: grope or feel in search of something
_examples: He felt for his wallet

synsets.definition: examine by touch
_examples: Feel this soft cloth!
The customer fingered the sweater

synsets.definition: examine (a body part) by palpation
_examples: The nurse palpated the patient's stomach
The runner felt her pulse

synsets.definition: find by testing or cautious exploration
_examples: He felt his way around the dark room

synsets.definition: produce a certain impression
_examples: It feels nice to be home again

synsets.definition: pass one's hands over the sexual organs of
_examples: He felt the girl in the movie theater

knowledges.origin_sent: The way he makes me feel about myself.
